Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2013 07:57PM - edited Nov 16, 2013 08:01PM by gtgirl Were you nauseous from the anesthesia and weren't aware of that affect? If I am not medicated prior during and after, I am nauseous and vomit. I am glad things got better. I wasn't told it was real painful, but I will be taking my medication as long as I need it. I am nervous about the SNB and the radioactive injections to my areola. I also was told by a Anesthesia Doctor at pre op that they wake you up in the operating room and you may still have your tube down your throat!? What? I didn't read too much into it. I have woke up in the operating room 10 years ago for my hysterectomy, but I don't remember anything, just that I woke up and they were finished. I also had sedation for my surgical biopsy a month ago and woke up at the end, when someone told me that they had to put my binder on. I am thinking this is protocol and I won't know if the tube is still in or not. I don't want to remember that part. I dislike the groggy feeling and the nasty taste in your mouth after.

Posts.Content: gtgirl wrote: Hello-I have been reading in this forum for a couple weeks.  I was hesitant to post.  I finally decided too.  I have not been diagnosed with anything.  I was told at my last Mammogram a couple weeks ago that I have microcalcifications on my left breast 1cm, which the grouping is the concern birads 4.  I had a ultrasound which I was told looked good.  No lumps or masses. What I found very strange this year during my additional views, is when my left breast was compressed, I had some discharge after she lifted up the machine.  The Tech said that is normal when your breast is compressed and if it was bloody, then there would be a concern.  I never had experienced that before.  I was pretty freaked out.  I was then told by the Radiologist that I needed a possible surgical biopsy with wire localization.  She also stated I think after my fiance asked a question that 10% chance of DCIS Stage 0 within the duct.  Ok, honestly that totally freaked me out worse.  So for 10 days I waited to see the Breast Surgeon and was a total wreck.  I cried, thinking the worse, couldn't sleep, my mind was going crazy.  After seeing my Breast Surgeon, I felt a little better and she explained the procedure to me.  I go on October 16th.  I still lay in bed at night and can't shut my mind off.  I am terrified of the procedure due to having a very RARE bleeding disorder.  I am going to one of the best hospitals an hour away from my home and I do have faith in everyone involved in my care.  This just complicates the situation due to having to be pre-medicated prior, during and watching for anything unsual after.  My anxiety is unbearable at times.  I know I have to do this, no if's ands or butts about it.  Due to my RARE bleeding disorder (which is a platelet dysfunction) when I had my baseline at age 35, they found microcalcifications on my right breast.  It also was a birads 4 and was marked for a core biopsy.  After the Radiologist talked to me and my family, my Hematologist and Breast Surgeon, they felt ok about waiting 6 months for another Mammogram.  At my 6 months, nothing changed, they remained stable. They then marked probably bengin.  I went another 6 months with the same.  I then went a year, with the same no changes they remained stable.  I have been going for a year the past couple and everything is still unchanged and stable on my right breast which I was told.  The focus is my left breast per my Breast Surgeon at this time.  I had a total hysterectomy at age 30 with taking hormones for almost 9 years and stopped last November.  I am doing well without them.  It amazes me the different opinions physicians say about taking hormones.  It was my choice to stop at age 39 and I am glad I did.  I only go to reputable sites.  The computer can make you sick if you go elsewhere and not reputable sites.  I just need to get my mindset right and continue to pray and remember God is in control, and will take care of me! Surgery 10/16/2013 Lumpectomy: Left; Mastectomy Dx 10/23/2013, DCIS, Left, <1cm, Stage 0, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER-/PR- Surgery 11/20/2013 Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Microcalcifications, heterogeneously dense, wire/surgical gtgirl gtgirl

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2013 12:04PM gtgirl wrote: AZwordmom, thank you for the kind words.  You are so right about not staying up late on the internet.  This site can also ramp up my anxiety, but I try to only stay in a couple forums. I am trying to remain positive and put all my faith in God.  The waiting is the hardest part.  It will be a month and a few days when I have my wire localization surgical biopsy.  I am praying since mine is so small, my BS will remove it all.  I don't know though.  She mentioned just removing a sample of tissue.  I spoke to the Nurse in the Breast Care Clinic and I told her about how much anxiety I have, as I also have a panic disorder.  I told her there is NO way I could do the wire localization without something to help calm my anxiety and she told me to discuss this with pre-op.  I do have anxiety medicine that I take prn, but I am worried about taking it the day of due to being sedated for the surgical part of it.  I am hoping all works out.

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2013 01:04PM gtgirl wrote: I had my wire localization and surgical biopsy yesterday. Wire localization was 10 mins, 20 mins total. That Radiologist was wonderful! I did have half dose of versed prior. My surgical biopsy went well and the BS stated she got a good sample of tissue. I did not go under general it is called MAPS. I should know my results by Monday or Tuesday. I have a binder on that I can not take off or peak until I get a call on my results. I am very sore and have been resting today.

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2015 03:58PM gtgirl wrote: My understanding of ER PR negative DCIS Stage 0 is that our cancer is not hormone fed and there is not a medication for us to take. I was offered a clinical trial if I would of opted for radiation. I would of been given a placebo or herceptin. The more I learn and read, hercpetin is given to people with HER2 positive, so this makes me wonder what my HER2 status would of been. Most people are not tested for HER2 with DCIS Stage 0.

Posts.Content: gtgirl wrote: I am not sure if this is the right forum to post this in.  I was searching this site for stable microcalcifications and any input.  I have read some posts from Beesie moderator and others.  I had my baseline at age 35 just a few weeks before turning 36.  I received a letter in the mail stating I needed to come back for additional views.  I then was told the Radiologist recommended a biopsy.  I right away made an appointment at The U of M in Ann Arbor Michigan.  It was a second opinion.  I then was told the same, but after the Radiologist talked with my BS and Hematologist, they felt waiting 6 months was ok.  I have had 6 month check ups with no change for two years and I have had yearly check ups the past two years with all stable, no changes.  So, it has been 5 years it will be 5 years in March.  My next mammogram is September.  I have been stressing out worrying "what if I have BC" in this breast?  I was told when I was diagnosed with BC in my left and prior to my surgical biopsy, that my right and left breast ARE different.  My diagnose of BC in my left was microcalcifications.  I have dense breasts.  I am told they aren't concerned about my right breast, but can't say that new calcs will not show up.  So much different information I read.  My goal is to have my right breast removed in the Spring. Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2014 09:46AM gtgirl wrote: Beesie, I am waiting on responses from my BS/NP.  I feel that since my hormone receptors are ER/PR - that I am at a even higher risk for breast cancer in my right breast.  This is just why I want to have my right breast removed.  As I have stated, I have very rare bleeding disorder and this complicates things.  I will be 41 at the end of March, I am young.  I was told recently in my support group that truly made me upset, that most likely I am HER2- meaning TNBC.  I have NEVER been told this by my BS or the Radiation Oncologist (when I spoke to him about my options).  I was told that with DCIS, they don't test for HER2.  Maybe other Hospitals do.  I was not genetically tested either.  I don't know why?  I have one sister 17 months older, neither of us have children and we aren't going to have any.  I had a hysterectomy at age 30 with all my female parts removed.

Posts.Content: gtgirl wrote: I have dense breast tissue. My mammogram showed asymmetry, so I had to go in for additional views, then a spot compression which they took two. I had a ultrasound after which the Radiologist came out and told me I had a tiny mass and is indeterminate, she kept on saying over and over it’s so tiny. She then told me her recommendations were an ultrasound guided biopsy. I’m going crazy in my head not knowing what I am facing. I read my report. I googled some words. Ovoid was one, hypoechoic, posterior acoustic shadowing and indiatinct.
